title: Robert Downey Jr 'appreciates' Martin Scorsese's views on Marvel films
text:
Robert Downey Jr. was diplomatic in his reaction to feted filmmaker Martin Scorsese's recent remarks that Marvel Films are 'not cinema'.

The Avengers: Endgame star made his feelings during an interview on The Howard Stern Show Monday from Sirius/XM's new Hollywood studio.

'It's his opinion,' Downey said. 'I appreciate his opinion because I think it's like anything. We need all of the different perspectives so we can come to center and move on.'

Careful: Robert Downey Jr. was diplomatic in his reaction to feted filmmaker Martin Scorsese's recent remarks that Marvel Films are 'not cinema'

Legendary filmmaker Scorsese had told Variety over the weekend: 'Honestly, the closest I can think of [Marvel films], as well made as they are, with actors doing the best they can under the circumstances, is theme parks.'

'It isn’t the cinema of human beings trying to convey emotional, psychological experiences to another human being,' concluded the Oscar winning director.

Downey, noting that the franchise 'plays in theaters,' said he was glad to hear Scorsese's take.

La La Land: The iconic broadcaster delivered a show from the new SiriusXM Hollywood facility

Downey also said that the MCU's success at the box office has been a game-changer in the industry.

'There's a lot to be said about how these genre movies - and I was happy to be a part of the "problem," if there is one - denigrated the art form of cinema,' said the Zodiac star.

'When you come in like a stomping beast and you eliminate competition in such a demonstrative way, it's phenomenal.'

Established: Stern's radio show began airing in LA in 1991 from its NYC headquarters

Bad motherf**ker: However, not all those in the Marvel Cinematic Universe were as conciliatory in their tone as Robert. Samuel L. Jackson [seen here over the weekend] fired back at Scorsese.

However, not all those in the Marvel Cinematic Universe were as conciliatory in their tone as Robert.

Samuel L. Jackson fired back at Scorsese in an interview with Variety over the weekend.

Jackson - who has starred as Nick Fury in 13 films as well as playing a small role in Scorsese's film Goodfellas - told the weekly: 'I mean that’s like saying Bugs Bunny ain’t funny. Films are films. Everybody doesn’t like his stuff either.'

'Everybody’s got an opinion, so I mean it’s okay. Ain’t going to stop nobody from making movies.'

Director fight: James Gunn - who directed both Guardians Of The Galaxy films - also responded to Scorsese on Twitter by saying he was 'saddened' by the comment. Seen here in June last year

James Gunn - who directed both Guardians Of The Galaxy films - also responded to Scorsese on Twitter as he wrote: 'Martin Scorsese is one of my 5 favorite living filmmakers.

'I was outraged when people picketed The Last Temptation of Christ without having seen the film. I’m saddened that he’s now judging my films in the same way.'

Despite the comments, Gunn continued to praise The Departed director and even expressed excitement over his latest project.

Gunn, 53, added: 'That said, I will always love Scorsese, be grateful for his contribution to cinema, and can’t wait to see The Irishman.'

He concluded his Twitter thread by posting: ''I'm not saying religious zealotry is the same as not liking my movies, or in the same category.'

Perspective: 'I was outraged when people picketed The Last Temptation of Christ without having seen the film. I’m saddened that he’s now judging my films in the same way,' wrote Gunn

Karen Gillan starred in both Guardians Of The Galaxy films directed by Gunn as she defended the filmmaker after Scorsese's comments.

Gillan, 31, said of the American filmmaker to The Hollywood Reporter at the Veuve Clicquot Polo Classic in Los Angeles: "He [Gunn] injects so much of his own personality, his sense of humor...that's a very big representation of who he is as a person and therefore it's very cinematic. He's an artist.'

She also answered whether or not she fell into the same way of thinking about film as Scorsese as she said: 'I would absolutely say that Marvel movies are cinema. Cinema is storytelling with visuals.'
